12/28/66
C.R. Logsdon
% Y.M.C.A.
936 St Charles Ave
New Orleans, LA
70130
Jack Conroy
701 Fisk Avenue
Moberly, MO 65270.
Dear Jack,
Bill Henderson told me you retired to Moberly. Living in a small town can provide as much alienation as a large city, However; you can be more fortwrite [sic] in knowing more about the alienated. There is the advantage of being a small town philosopher, always available to freighten [sic] more of the alienated. I discovered that in Mobely Mo. More people know who they hated

and enjoyed it more than love. You can freely hate as many as you like, but dare not love one. Hate is feared, but love is the butt of all Jokes.
Now, let's get down to business! I used to be puzzled: Why, you were for Rockefeller; Now, I know! His interests, when properly persued in the Pacific (oil, copper, etc.) to the neglect of Morgan's investment chanels in Europe, Can quickly collapse the whole

investment structure of World-wide capitalism. The European Capitalists know more about inventing in, and exploiting, the capital markets of the World than any other group. The Rockefeller family and their business and political friends lack a direct interest in European capitalism; they have committed the U.S.A. to endless wars in Asia without understanding its ultimate results to all

4
Capital interests everywhere, including their own. The American Capitalists are going to destroy all their interest by an over committment[sic] to violence in Asia. WALT ROSTOW, of the State Department is Rockefeller's advisor on economic growth and development. He is an 18th & 19th century HISTORICAL economist. Devoid of any political understanding of the 20th century. Every more of JOHNSON'S is under the guidance

5
of ROSTOW - who sits in the White House nite and day - ever closer to Johnson all of Johnson's cronies from Texas have fled Walt's influence.
I guess you are prepared to follow William Manchester's book condensation in Look - Starting in January?
Bin Henderson wrote, said, "I'm the last of the MoHicans in Chicago. Even Jack Conroy has fled to Moberly, Mo."
Highest Regards,
c. R. Logsdon

Note: he writes in mixed capital and lower case letters
1   2/18/67   
Dar Jack:

 It WAS REAL GOOD to HEAR From you. The REWARDS of Life ARE too Few; And, penny pinching

on social security in Moberly, or Malden, Missouri is NOT one of them. I have sent you a CR?oCE?
CooKBook to Help CHeer up your stomach.

I HAVE AFFILIATED WITH the UNITARIAN CHURCH IN NEW ORLEANS; AND CHURCH LOBBy;

WHILE I WILL BE MOST HAPPY to Display your two Books - "The DISINHERITED And "ANypLACE
BUT HERE." SEND 4 copies of EACH to me at the 936 St. CHARLES ADDRESS. AND BILL ME FOR the
same. I will MAKE your NAME KNOWN to the LIBERAL ELEMENT IN NEW ORLEANS, WHICH is one of the only
TWO CENTERS OF CULTURE IN ALL OF DIXIE - ATLANTA IS the OTHER.

he writes in upper and lower case
2

I came to NEW ORLEANS For the WINTER; AND ALL of My FRIENDS IN CHICAGO ARE CONVINCED,

I AM PSYCHIC; SINCE The great Storm struck. SOME people MIGHT DESIRE WARMER WEATHER; BUT
For the NORTHERNER, LIKE ME, IT HAS BEEN QUITE pleasant. It is my first experience to see the flowers
bloom and HEAR the birds sing - ALL WINTER THROUGH.

You, MARK TWAIN, JACK LONDON, BILL HAYWOOD, AND THOUSANDS OF OTHERS, INCLUDING MYSELF

HAVE Bumed? all over THIS COUNTRY; AND THAT IS WHY, YOU CAN SPEAK the LANGUAGE, SO WELL UNDERSTOOD BY
the DISINHERITED AND FOR THOSE WHO CAN ACCEPT ANY PLACE BUT HERE.

I DO BELIEVE; THAT, WITHIN THE NEXT 15 YEARS, THE TIME, WILL WITNESS THE SOVIET UNION OUT PRODUCING the

U.S. IN TOTAL WEALTH WITH A RAPIDLY ADVANCING MORAL LEADERSHIP; AND THIS WILL COINCIDE WITH AN EVER

3
INCREASING MORAL COLLAPSE WITHIN OUR COUNTRY. ITS GOING to BRING ABOUT 
open AND HEATED DIALOGUE to AN LEVSES? OF AMERICAN SOCIETY FORCING the
DISCUSSION OF POLITICAL ISSUES UPON EVERYONE. YOU AND I ARE, YET, GOING TO
WITNESS: THE PERSONAL POPULARITY OF RADICAL THOUGHT, IN THIS COUNTRY; THEN
YOU WILL HAVE TO EMERGE FROM MOBBERLy INTO the FULL EXCITEMENT OF AMERICAN LIFE, 
AND BE YOUNG AGAIN.

 HIGHEST REGARDS,
  Clarence

3/13/67
DEAR JACK:

 GOT YOUR TWO Copies of DISINHERITED; AND The CHECK # 510 IS INCLOSED For 39 00; I

DON'T WANT OR NEED the COMMISSION. I AM LOOKING FORWARD TO: aNYPlace but here.

 NEW ORLEANS IS A GOOD PLACE FOR PATRONIZING RESTAURANTS. I AM LEARNING

to EAT IN THOSE PLACES; THAT ATTACT [sic] BOTH the RICH AD the POOR; THEY ARE CROWDED
AND THE FOOD IS GOOD, ALSO CHEAPER.

ANY PLACE THAT HAS LOTS OF IDLE WAITERS, WHO ARE Too poliTE, ARE the ONES WITH THE

HIGH PRICES.

I CAN WITH EFFORT EAT ONE Dozen RAW OYSTERS, SIX

1/3/68
DEAR JACK:

Happy New Year!

I Am Back in New Orleans for the Winter - Drinking Scotch, Bourbon, Gin And Vodka;
It's Hard to stay away in the Winter and Face Chicago's Weather in my Advancing years.

If it Takes a Counter Revolution to stimulate Revolution (According to MARX), LBJ is

the man to supply  (over)

2
iT; I am Betting: HE win Get Another 4 years to Further Damage the Capitalist System.

Ever, Since, Roosevelt Cut Loose From the Restraints of the Gold-Standard - THE economy

Has Been Running Without A THrottling Governor; it will Eventually Produce the CHAOS No One
Thinks Can Ever Be True. "THE DISINHERITED" Will Become the Classic of the 20th Century.

3
LBJ and the ROCKEFELLERS Must Take Over THE WHOLE WORLD bEFORE theIR
operations Run Out of Gold; And, THAT, My Friend, is some Big doings. The Cry is 
Rising, "Keep your paper Money, Give Me Gold." All Nations Are in Trouble over Gold-ToDay.
Only Socialist Countries Are Immune.

THERE is A Reason why the Russi - crossed out Soviet Ruple Has Been Stabilized At $1.12.

4
in Gold. It May Eventually Become THE Standard Currency or the World. Gold Has No
Flag, No Country, No Religion, No system; IT Justifies   Its Own Existence; And Value; IT
is Welcome Everywhere And So Can A Gold Ruple Be A Safe investment For THE Richest
Families. At First, IT sounds silly; to say, the Capitalists Will Be forced to Underwrite

5
THE REVOLUTION to Save Their Fortunes; But, Stranger,
Things Have Happened in History.

 your Friend
 C.R. LOGSDON
 111 CHARTRES S[?]
 NEW ORLEANS, LA 70130

P.S. I Sent some Back Copies of the Nation to you   CRL

If you should Come to N.O. I Can Arrange Bed & Board;

If, you Notify Me.    CRL

2/17/68
Dear Jack:

I NEVER KNEW THAT Could Happen in Moberly, Mo; until I picked up my paper today.
 I suppose you know most of the people involved.
 I Hope you were not involved in the Accident. Twelve people Killed in a Small Town

Tavern Fire is a Big Tragedy For A Small Community Worse, Everybody Knows Everybody.

At My AGE, I CAN'T Afford to Lose A Friend; let Me Know How you are And THE Story ABOUT

the Clipping inclosed. [sic]

  C.R. Logsdon

5/6/68
Jack Conroy
701 Fisk Ave.
Moberly, Mo. 65270
Dear Jack:

THANKS For your Review on RICHARD WRIGHT; It Brought Me up to date on some things

Regarding Him.

ALSO, IT is the First issue; I Have Seen on the Letter-Resitt?
Keep up the Good And Noble Work; Its Always Good to Know and Understand Why Are the Pros'

and All the Anti's Efforts,, Have Little to do with Speeding up a Slowing Down the Momentum of the
Revolution - A social force - That Does Not Wait for Everybody to Be come Educated Before Making
iT's presence Known and Felt By all.    (over)

2.

 THE TOUGHER the AGENCIES of GOVERNMENT TALK AND ACT  The LESS is THEIR power And

INFLUENCE to BE HEARD AND FELT. THE MEANhST [sic] TALKING GOVERNMENT ON EARTH WAS the
KREWSKY GOVERNMENT DuRing iTS LAST 24 HOURS of LiFE. on EARTH - crossed out

 THE REVOLT OF YOUTH iN the UNIVERSITIES iS the AWAKENING SOUND OF the MORNING; AND, the DEATH

GROANS of the ALMIGHTY DOLLAR iS the Ever RiNGiNG ALARM - to PREVENT -
THEIR RETURN TO SLUMBER ^ THIS THE OLD PROTESTANT ETHIC; WHiCH The Roman CATHOLICS ADOPTED, 
ALSO, AFTER the REFORMATION ^ That is Dying: "WORK HARD; SAVE YOUR MONEY; TURN IT INTO CAPITOL;
INVEST IT To EARN INTEREST; Sents? AND Profits; to BECOME A CAPITALIST AND DO AWAY WITH POVERTY."
ONLY THE MOST MORALLY DEGENERATE OF AMERICAN YOUTH ADAPTED THEIR Ling? or Lirg? to

3
SUCH YANKS AFTER the CiViL WAR - ALL THAT IS  - EXCEPT the HONEST BACKWARD YOEMAN [sic] on the
sOIl OR THE rEMAInINg fROntIER, The YouTH oF TODAy is ForceD to SEEK GREATER AND MORE M?ANickr?
VALUES; AND Or ALL the PAiN, There is NONE oF the TRANSITION or VALUES.  THIS IS the MEANiNG words crossed out
BEHiND ALL OF the GROANS AND HOWLS GOiNG up ALL OVER the LAND  -AND THOSE NEW VALUES MUST
OF NECESSITY BE TRULY REVOLUTIONARY VALUES. to FiT the New SiTUATiON.

  HIGHEST REGARDS,
    C.R. Logsdon

Note: writer prints in mixed upper and lower case. I am transcribing lower case except for beginning of sentences & proper names etc.
5/15/68
Jack Conroy
701 Fisk
Moberly, Mo. 65270
Dear Jack:

I was discussing you to my boy a few days ago; you know; he used "DISINHERITED" in one of his classes last year.

He said, "If we have the available funds next year, we may invite Conroy to the University, provided we can meet
his fee."

 The New Orleans branch of LSU (NO) attracts a better and more alert student and professor than Baton Rouge and as

a result the main University is afraid to ask the legislature for the necessary funds to operate the branch; It might
quickly grow larger and more important than the present school.    (over)

Note: writer prints in mixed upper and lower case. I am transcribing lower case except for beginning of sentences & proper names etc.
2

 I am leaving N.O. on 5/17/68 - going to Ozark Mountains or N.W. Arkansas - near the post office of Limestone, Arkansas - 72464 %

Dewey Stone. Several excellent fishing streams are in the area; or where I am  going there is the little and big  piney Rivers and Hurricane
Creek, which is about 1/4 of a mile from the house.

 I was amazed, last year, to learn; that, those men live in the hills may be 5 miles from the nearest neighbor; but they know everybody within

a hundred miles.

 Most of the land - crossed out high land in the area is a part of the Ozark National Forest; and, its a big deer season country in the Fall.

The natives round up every cow, ball [sic] and horse; and themselves wear red or bright orange clothing during the deer season - to keep
from getting shot.

Note: writer prints in mixed upper and lower case. I am transcribing lower case except for beginning of sentences & proper names etc.
3

 It will be a hot season this summer, according to my son who predicted last summer's "hot summer' a year ahead of the events.
 I have a feeling; that, anything - crossed out any western spokesman, for his establishment, can only make political boo-boos; no mater [sic], 

who the establishment may be repossessed - crossed out written above: camp o s?oot?

 Events eat-up and use-up anyone close the ^ facing event; their flags wave; but their spirit is gone. Can you believe and realize to day; that,

the people of the 30's actually thought F.D.R. would solve their larger social problems.

  Your friend,
   Clarence

at top J? - possibly A for Adeline & Emil Martel sends N'Year greetings
Jack Conroy
701 Fisk
Moberly, MO 65270

1
6/28/70
Jack Conroy
701 Fisk
Moberly, Missouri 65270
Dear Jack:

I sit here in Los Angeles, holy drunk on beer, thinking of you and I want to inform you about a mutual friend,

Max or Emil Martel, whom you have known for many years. Max or Emil Martel, has been preparing for
many years a Book, which he has entitled "John Lock's Nightmare or the Rise and Fall of the Confidence Man."
It is presently about 900 pages long, all done in Inbnic [sic: Iambic] Pentameter Pater - crossed out Poetry. It is something
that will sell in today's market. He should be encouraged by you to submit it.

You should write to: Emil Martel, 527 N. Sycamore, Los Angeles 90036 and encourage him!

2

I recently paid for address labels to be sent to you
Yours truly

label
Clarence R. Logsdon
Appleton Apts. 305
738 New Hampshire St.
Los Angeles, Calif. 90005
P.S. send me the names of your friends in LA, whom you think I shud [sic] know.

  Clarence

7/18/70
Dear Fare Jack:

Since there are 12 widows to one widower in Los Angeles, I spend my time in Arboretums &

Museums and stay away from the Sodom and Gomorrahs; Its here, but Philosophy best becomes
any man over 50.

I am sending an outline of the Ages of Man - I have produced with a Chicago friend, to whom, I

introduced to History. Today, he is fascinated with the subject. let me know, if you think anything
should be Added or eliminated.

Joe, my son, is in good health. This summer he is teaching a Summer Course in history at Louisiana

State Univ. at New Orleans. last year he was teaching at Lehigh Univ. in Penn. Next Fall he will be at the
Univ. of Chicago.

2
He will be pursuing research in his Black Studies. He is spending part of the Summer doing this work in
New Orleans and the state of Louisiana.

He is placing all his research work into a Non-Profit Corporation & all funds used to make purchases from

the Corporation are being devoted to additional research. There is a great deal about the Blacks in America not yet
discovered & written. Black America is almost an unknown quanity [sic].

I am writing Joe about your review in The American Book Collector.
   your friend
   old 2 gun Logsdon

April 17, 1970
Dear Mr Conroy

We have met only in print. My Father acted as mediator in distributing our writings. I admired your work and integrity

as did my Father, and I was pleased that you thought well of my work in Negro history. Your review was perceptive
and kind.

You were apparently the last person in contact with my Father. Your  opened letter of August 4 was on his table when

authorities opened his room for my inspection of his personal effects. He apparently died of a heart attack on August 6,
in his sleep. His body was discovered on August 10. I was notified the next day and arrived on August 13 to make
final arrangements.

Fighting off the vultures (his landlords, the coroner, the public administrator, his former wife, his

fellow tenants). I has his body cremated. He wanted to have his body donated to science, but it was too
severely decomposed. Instead I shall give him a radical's funeral. His ashes will be disposed in the Pacific,
in the Mississippi River at New Orleans (where I shall return temporarily), along the Appalachians (where
I had planned to vacation for a week before labor day), and finally in Haymarket Sq. on labor day in Chicago
(where I shall spend a year at the University of Chicago - Sept - June - 1461 E. 55th Place 60637).

He, of course, cared little about death; he thought only of life and its improvement. His last months fortunately were

spent discovering new scenery, people, and ideas. He loved the California climate and took cynical delight in
observing its insanities.\ I shall miss him and his kind.

I hope another generation of men with vision, humanity, and integrity like you, him and your

beleaguered band will appear. Perhaps he was awaiting them at the Pacific.

 Cordially,
  Joe Logsdon

P.S. You indicated in one letter to my father that you wished to have him send you copies of the
LA Free Press. I have arranged for a subscription. You should begin receiving it shortly.

I have been staying at Emil Martel's. He sends his greetings and says he will write - "if I have

something to say."

Lomax, John A.

see: Scarborough, Dorothy

405 E. [?]th
NYC
Dear Jack -

Your letter's a month old & I'm sorry - but I've haven't answered any mail for a month. I can remember happier

and more reposeful Junes - had to climb out of a quagmire of debt... I've asked my pubs to send a review copy of the
books - I know you'll like it...I can't know where I'll be this Aug, possibly in Mexico, but call me when you're in town...
Nothing you could ever do to ^NBC TV would make me sore at you... Pardon this hurried note, but I feel like hell -

Yrs Faithfully     Alan
 Lomax

10/23/65
Marlboro
P.O. Box 5 [2?]
Dear Jack.

Thanks for lively? post card. Hope all is well with you. Am out of a job and

looking. - Do you know anyone who might want to hire a great heart and half a brain? have
abandoned NY Apt, and live in my house in Marlboro when I'm there.

Am in Danville ILL with C C Wilson. He suggests I help him start "just one more magazine.

Advocate. He advances a sound notion: that a World Association of mayors would find enough
in common (without the preconceived enmity, ill will, prejudice. Arms race & hair trigger
fingers) to diminish the War-Power Complex in time to achieve at least Atomic disarmament.
Might you have an interest in working on such a project - if you find time to write, send a carbon
copy to me here on the envelope address and a copy to Marlboro. don't know where I'll be or eat?

Regards -  Best to Gladys -    Bob Lorenz

ROBERT LORENZ
152 East 22nd Street
New York 10, N.Y.
Dear Jack,

You asked for Max & Florence Wiss
2469 E. 74th Place,
Chicago -
 Your memorial to Dreiser is great - You wield a mighty Penn - Hope you can live without old daily job

And husband youself [sic] and redracres? for writing the important Word You have so long had for us.

Henrietta Wiegal was there for dinner when your card and the copy of Inland arrived. She joins in best

Christmas wishes to both of you -

Sincerely   Bob L.

1-8-'62
Dear Jack,
Your Xmas note was great as usual. The review of Dr. dandy hearts is great, true. And all too
brief as was his life and writing time.   The letter to Geo. R. was returned by the P.O. or 
Superintendent of our Bldg. because we have not heard from him for a year. We are con-

cerned about him and don't know how or where to reach him.

Will be at the Essex Inn on 8th & Mich. Ave. for a week beginning the

26th - save time for a talk over - the Very Best to you.

  B.                                                 Gramercy 5-6816

ROBERT LORENZ
152 East 22nd Street
New York 10, N.Y.

  XMas 1967

card by Gordon Lindsay
File:Circle with map - Winning the Nations Crusade No. 1

in pencil  Lowe, Cora
Oct 1, 1959
Dear Jack family.

I know it is not good taste to answer a letter right the day you get it. but always after I hear from you

and believe me Jack I surely enjoy doing so, I want to talk back to you. Thanks for your concerns over
my mishap. I am better but not yet to steady on my feet. and I am recricering recovering slowly and
I must say painfully. Why do our family eat so much? About books Jack. the One that interested me greatly is
the "Jefferson Selleck" Novel. Carl Jones you see I can remember all those things he speaks of and it bears out
my faith in Hoover. I know you never liked him, but on page 14 and 15 He said "Mr Hoover was already at work
correcting etc" And given another year I am sure it would have been

2
impossible for any thing to have happend [sic] that did happen" and he goes on to say
was Hoover to blaim? [sic] I would certainly say No etc. then later he says "I am very
glad to say - crossed out see that along with a re-evaluation of the 1920's, has come
a re-evaluation of Herbert Hoover also" and he also expresses My idea of F.D.R. so its a
great book. All tho I haaven't finished it yet but am enjoying it a lot. I Can't imagine any
one wanting rented books when Sent Such good ones as you send. No I didn't know Thelma 
was "expecting" I hope its a "tom Conroy". glad Jimmy is with his Aunt too. good for him also
for poor Gladys. tell her to take it as easy as She possibly can. I know its hard. Yes I agree all the
way with you about KohrshSe? I watched and listened to him every time he

3
striped her, by then the policeman were there one took his coat wraped [sic] her in it 
led her in the house. she simply died away had to take her home call the Doctor he of Course
gave her a shab and nerve medicine they had to take out their guns to try to subdo [sic] tommy
but he cursed them, screamed at the top of his voice they took him to fulton, Said he is really
dangerous, freda went to see him yesterday, told me today He is kept "Doped" Said she didn't tell
Isobell to much about it for she worrys so. I think he will never be allowed to come home again 
which is right Walter the dunce, says He is only nervous! I just talked to Henderson He ask how you
were I told him I got a letter today. He said he is sending you another letter tonight. He also he hoped
you would come to Moberly to live when you retire.    over

4
I didn't mean to write such a long letter of I would have not used both sides, but me I have so much
I want to tell you I never say it all. You will be worn out. So will close with this - I can't say honey
how thankfull [sic] I am youres [sic] over your worst. be Careful now. let us hear from you. We love
you very much.

John sends his best to you and is glad as he puts it ^glad you are On your feet.
 Love  Cora and John.

Don't let on to the Harrison's I told you of tommy. Sis will tell you when she sees you.
Mrs Grolier said tell you Moberly is still here and would sure welcome you home.

512 Greenfield Road
Kansas City, Missouri
May 13, 1975
Dear Mr. & Mrs. Conroy:

I'm sure you will think I'm off my rocker but I just have to write you. I'm sure I know you and yet I'm confused. I am a former

Moberly resident having lived there all my life until I married in 1935 and I came to K.C. do you remember a family by the
name of Hammons? My father was Jeff Hammons and I'm sure he knew your Father. and if I'm not mistaken I am thinking your maiden
name was Walker. I remember a Minnie B Walker and I am thinking she may have been your Sister. And then again I'm not sure. What
was your maiden name?  I read the article in K.C. star about Mr. Conroy and it said his wife's name is Gladys. I have an older sister by
the name of Ann. She says she has some pictures taken when she was young and there is a Gladys in them but no last name. I've heard
My Dad speak of Jack Conroy many times I also have a sister between me & Ann Her name is Bertha. I am Elsie (the youngest) And 
Im 62. Bert is 68 & Ann is 71. So I'll never be satisfied until I find out who you are. Ann lives here (Prairie Village)

and Bert lives in Hannibal. There are very few people living in Moberly that I know. Mama & Papa passed away in '55 & '56.
Sometime if you are in K.C. call us or come and see us. I would like to hear from you and maybe I'll not be confused. I'm sure
you are very proud of your husband & I hope someday I'll be able to meet and see you. So will be looking for a letter soon.
By the way Ann was called Anna when she lived in Moberly (that is her right name) but she has always been called Ann by us.
Maybe you don't know her & I am sorry I am bothering you.

 Lovingly
   Elsie Hammons Lowe.

September 3, 1975
Dearest Conroys:

I'm so sorry I haven't answered your letter but it just seems like I'm too slow in everything I do now. My sisters were happy

to hear about you. Bert came and visited us about 5 weeks. But of course she felt like she had to go back to Hannibal. Too bad
she can't live closer to us. It's too far for her to drive alone. So we went after her and then took her home later. We went through
Moberly when we took her home and stopped at the cemetary [sic] at left some flowers for Mama & Papa's graves. Ann is having
her problems too. She has her husband in a Nursing home and still hoping she can bring him home soon. He had a  series of small
strokes (of which they were not aware of) and it damaged his brain slightly. He's in good health and his mind is OK at least 80% of
the time, but when he was at home he needed almost constant watching. If she can find someone to stay with her at night she could
manage fine. These nursing homes are much too expensive. It costs her $23 00 per day just for his room and board. You mentioned
Gladys Golden Kelly in your letter. We have wondered if Mrs. Golden is still alive. I don't think I've heard from her since she lived
in Moberly. I heard Mr. Golden & Ivan were gone and maybe Irvin. You told us about the Burkes. You said all the Burkes

are gone now. I didn't know if you meant Carlotta is dead or just not there in Moberly. She was a dear girl to me.
I remember when I was in the 5th grade at West Park she selected Jim Heifner (who was killed in a sled mishap
when he was in high school) and Myself to sing together and many times we were invited to sing and I remember
one time we sang for the Rotary Club and after we were through a gentleman came up to me and asked me if I had
a sister by the name of Ann. When I told him yes, he said, You tell her I said hello and I am Oak Hunter. Carlotta
was a wonderful and talented musician and I really loved her. Yes, we were all members of Immanuel Baptist Church,
but Ann cannot remember Josephine Kelly. We were a poor family, but there are times when Ann talks about how
little we had and thinks we should have had more, but you know, no men ever worked any harder to feed his family
than my Papa did. So I know he did the best he could and thats good enough for me. Would you believe when Papa
came to Missouri in about 1900 he was worth in cash about $30,000 and owned quite a bit of land in Kentucky. he
owned a mill in Bynumville and Mama had the only millinery shop around there for miles. But he made bad trades
and had too many non-paying customers and lost all of it. I was about one year old when they moved from

Salisbury to Moberly. I really don't know of any enemies Papa ever had so regardless of how we lived I still have much
love and respect for my Dad & Mother. I still don't know have much but I'm happy and we have 2 children and 8 grandchildren
of which we are very proud of. Our oldest grand child is 14 1/2 and the youngest is 4 1/2. All good children and they all love their
"Grandma & Grandpa". Well I didn't intend to write a book. I'm going to get "the Anvil" sometime & read it. I enjoyed your letter
so much and thank you for writing me. Ann gave me a picture to send to Gladys (you don't have to return it) and we think its
Gladys. If we are ever in Moberly ^and can stay a few hours I'll either call you or drop by.

 Love and best wishes always
  Elsie Hammons Lowe
